ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded weekly lecture
Weekly lecture, seminar three times a week, and writing assignments (including papers).

While mot of the class was conducted as a virtual seminar of 12 other students, the directed studies program more broadly has both a recorded lecture component and supplementary meetings that take the form of live lectures with the potential to ask questions.
Recorded lecture and virtual seminar
recorded lecture
Recorded Lecture.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to better analyze and evaluate philosophical arguments by breaking them down into argument-premise form. I also improved the quality and understanding of philosophical writing. Through class discussion, I was able to consider the texts we read in greater depth, engaging in a fruitful dialogue with the authors to better comprehend their often difficult ideas.
Engaging with philosophy for the first time - learning how to interpret philosophical sources and writing papers.

I learned both truths about reality, God, and other philosophical truths. I also, quite helpfully, learned how and what it means to think philosophically. How to construct and deconstruct an argument, how to poke holes in arguments and articulate those problems. I have not only found these skills helpful for my philosophical/academic writing, but to how I think about the world and argue more generally. I have really found a difference.
Reconstructing philosophical arguments, reading and discussing logical flaws, writing philosophy paper
Improved close reading ability. Learnt how to write a philosophy paper

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: As with most DS courses, the reading and workload of this class were pretty heavy; however, Professor Werner offered excellent advice on how to manage it and his weekly reading questions allowed me to dig deeper into the most significant parts of the text. His writing feedback was always quick and incredibly thorough. I entered this class unfamiliar with philosophical writing and techniques for analysis, but Professor Werner devoted class time to properly explaining them and giving us ample class time and writing assignments to practice these skills.
It is quite difficult to get a handle on the subjects quickly, so make sure to reach out for as much help as you need, which Prof. Werner is really open to.

I think the course does a good job of spanning a lot of material and picking out the most important ideas in that material. One weakness embedded within that structure is the difficulty of giving some works the time thy might deserve. It feels at times as though we move on from certain works quickly. Another weakness was the amount of work on top of the already rigorous/heavy philosophy work in the form of the extra assignments. These were not bad in principle (and actually quite helpful), but could have been more spaced out or shorter potentially.
Too much content covered in the program

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Andy's use of the 3-day, 50-minute format (as opposed to the usual 2-day, 75-minute format for DS classes) was extremely helpful in reducing screen fatigue and the slow pace that can plague longer class sessions. Andy's virtual hours were very helpful, and his willingness to make time to meet with students virtually was great.
This course was among my most accessible; the handouts we were given were very helpful and kept me on track regardless of Zoom fatigue.
The course did an optimally good job engaging me given the COVID-19 pandemic circumstances. There is nothing else I can imagine being done in that regard.
Handouts were amazing

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, especially Andy's section if you want a more guided and structured experience.

This is a great class to develop a deeper appreciation for and understanding of the complexity and nuance that may be found in philosophy. I would recommend it to anyone who is willing to put in the requisite effort to gain better writing, reading, discussion, and analysis skills. The payoff is great, but the effort needed is similarly great.
Yes - but be prepared to do extra work.

I certainly would recommend this course to another student. The material is extremely interesting, the professor is great, and the way it changes how you think is tangible and profound. If I could, I would certainly take the course again.
Yes, an eye opening and intellectually challenging course that helps you push your thinking further
Yes
